verses.verse: the Jews established and imposed it upon themselves and their descendants and all who would (Esth. 8:17; (Is. 56:3, 6); Zech. 2:11) join them, that without fail they should celebrate these two days every year, according to the written instructions and according to the prescribed time,

that these days should be remembered and kept throughout every generation, every family, every province, and every city, that these days of Purim should not fail to be observed among the Jews, and that the memory of them should not perish among their descendants.
Then Queen Esther, (Esth. 2:15) the daughter of Abihail, with Mordecai the Jew, wrote with full authority to confirm this (Esth. 8:10; 9, 21) second letter about Purim.
And Mordecai sent letters to all the Jews, to (Esth. 1:1) the one hundred and twenty-seven provinces of the kingdom of Ahasuerus, with words of peace and truth,

to confirm these days of Purim at their appointed time, as Mordecai the Jew and Queen Esther had prescribed for them, and as they had decreed for themselves and their descendants concerning matters of their (Esth. 4:3, 16) fasting and lamenting.
So the decree of Esther confirmed these matters of Purim, and it was written in the book.
Mordecai’s Advancement And King Ahasuerus imposed tribute on the land and on (Gen. 10:5; Ps. 72:10; Is. 11:11; 24:15) the islands of the sea.

Now all the acts of his power and his might, and the account of the greatness of Mordecai, (Esth. 8:15, 9:4) to which the king advanced him, are they not written in the book of the (Esth. 6:1) chronicles of the kings of Media and Persia?

For Mordecai the Jew was (Gen. 41:40, 43, 44; 2 Chr. 28:7) second to King Ahasuerus, and was great among the Jews and well received by the multitude of his brethren, (Neh. 2:10; Ps. 122:8, 9) seeking the good of his people and speaking peace to all his countrymen.

Job and His Family in Uz There was a man (1 Chr. 1:17) in the land of Uz, whose name was (Ezek. 14:14, 20; James 5:11) Job; and that man was (Gen. 6:9; 17:1; (Deut. 18:13)) blameless and upright, and one who ((Prov. 16:6)) feared God and shunned evil.
And seven sons and three daughters were born to him.

Also, his possessions were seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen, five hundred female donkeys, and a very large household, so that this man was the greatest of all the people of the East.
And his sons would go and feast in their houses, each on his appointed day, and would send and invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

So it was, when the days of feasting had run their course, that Job would send and sanctify them, and he would rise early in the morning (Gen. 8:20; (Job 42:8)) and offer burnt offerings according to the number of them all. For Job said, “It may be that my sons have sinned and (1 Kin. 21:10, 13) cursed God in their hearts.” Thus Job did regularly.
Satan Attacks Job’s Character Now (Job 2:1) there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan also came among them.
And the LORD said to Satan, “From where do you come?” So Satan answered the LORD and said, “From ((1 Pet. 5:8)) going to and fro on the earth, and from walking back and forth on it.”
Then the LORD said to Satan, “Have you considered My servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, one who fears God and shuns evil?”
So Satan answered the LORD and said, “Does Job fear God for nothing?

(Job 29:2-6; Ps. 34:7; Is. 5:2) Have You not made a hedge around him, around his household, and around all that he has on every side? ((Ps. 128:1, 2; Prov. 10:22)) You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.
(Job 2:5; 19:21) But now, stretch out Your hand and touch all that he has, and he will surely (Is. 8:21; Mal. 3:13, 14) curse You to Your face!”
And the LORD said to Satan, “Behold, all that he has is in your power; only do not lay a hand on his person.” So Satan went out from the presence of the LORD.
